facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 821 to 823 of 1968 are appeals by special leave from the order dated August 18, 1966 of the Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 821 to 823 of 1968. Appeals by special leave from the order dated August 18, 1966 of the Calcutta High Court in Civil Rules Nos. 1827 F  to 1829 F  of 1966.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court dismissed Civil Rule Nos 1827 F to 1829 F of 1966 on August 18, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Jagadish Swarup Solicitor-General of India, P. Chatterjee and P. K. Chakravarti, for the appellant  in all the appeals . Mookherjee and S. C. Majumdar, for respondent No. 1  in As. Nos. 821 and 823 of 1968 .

facts.text: Applications under s. 5 of the Limitation Act, 1963 filed to excuse delay in filing three appeals against decision of Additional District Judge, Howrah dated June 27, 1963 in three Land Acquisition Reference Cases.

anchor.surface_text: These three appeals, by special leave, are directed against the companymon judgment and order dated August 18, 1966 of the Calcutta High Court dismissing Civil Rule Nos 827 F  to 829 F  of 1966, which were applications filed by the appellant under s. 5 of the Limitation Act, 1963, to excuse the delay in filing three appeals against the decision of the Additional District Judge, Howrah, dated June 27, 1963, in three Land Acquisition Reference Cases.

facts.text: First respondent is Howrah Municipality.

anchor.surface_text: In this judgment we are referring the ranks of the.parties AS in Civil Appeal No. 821 of 1968. Thee first respondent is the Howrah Municipality.

facts.text: Second respondent took lease of about 21 bighas 9 kotas of land from first respondent; respondents 3 and 4 took sub-lease from second respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The second respondent had taken a lease of about 21 bighas 9 kotas of land from the first respondent and respondents Nos. 3 and 4 have taken a sub- lease from the second respondent of the said area.

facts.text: About 41 bighas of land in Salkia, Howrah acquired by Government of West Bengal for market place.

anchor.surface_text: The circumstances leading up to the order of the High Court may be stated About 41 bighas of land situated in Salkia it Howrah were acquired by the Government of West Bengal for the purpose of utilising the same as market place at Howrah.

facts.text: Acquired land placed at disposal of Howrah Municipality on condition to use for public market, not for other purpose without govt permission.

anchor.surface_text: After, the acquisition, the entire land was placed at the disposal of the first respondent the Municipality, Howrah, on th e specific companydition that the said land was to be used for establishing a public market and that it would number be used for any other purpose without the permission of the Government.

facts.text: Agreement that land would be resumed if public market not established within reasonable time.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellant them was also an agreement that the land would be resumed in the event of a public market number being established within a reasonable time.

facts.text: Suit T.S. No. 15 of 1959 filed by second respondent decreed on January 25, 1960; suit No. 10 of 1959 by Municipality dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant. On January 25, 1960, the suit filed by the second respondent, namely, T.SNo. 15 of 1999 was decreed and the suit, No. 10 of 1959 filed by the Municipality was dismissed.

facts.text: T.S. No. 34 of 1961 for possession of 41 bighas decreed on July 21, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: It is, claimed by,the appellant that T. S. No. 34 of 1961 for possession of 4 1 bighas was decreed,.on July 21, 196 1.

facts.text: Binding nature of decree in T.S. No. 34 of 1961 disputed by respondents 2-4.

anchor.surface_text: We are particularly referring, to this aspect because companysiderable argument was advanced before us, particularly on behalf of the respondents Nos. 2 to 4 regarding the binding,nature of this- judgment. Mr. D. N. Mukherji, learned companynsel for respondents Nos. 2 to 4 urged that as the name of respondent No. 2 had been struck off from the array of defendants in the said suit, the decree therein is number binding either on the second respo ndent or his sub-lessees, respondents Nos. 3 and 4.

facts.text: Additional District Judge, Howrah decided three Land Acquisition References on June 27, 1963, making appellant liable for about Rs. 16,00,000 compensation.

anchor.surface_text: On June 27,1963, the Additional District Judge, Howrah, decided the three Land Acquisition References and made the appellant liable to pay companypensation of the sum of about Rs. 16,00,000.

facts.text: Decrees in Land Acquisition References signed on September 21, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The decrees in these references were signed on September 21 1963.

facts.text: Second respondent levied execution on basis of Award; appellant filed objection on August 27, 1964 under s.47 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: The second respondent on the basis of the Award, levied exe- cution and the appellant filed objection on August 27, 1964 under s. 47 C.P.C. on the ground that the Award is number executable in view of the decree in Title Suit No. 34 of 1961.

facts.text: Discovered on March 4, 1965 that no appeals filed against Land Acquisition judgment.

anchor.surface_text: It was on March 4, 1965, that it was discovered that the judgment of the Additional District Judge in the three Land Acquisition References had number been appealed against.

facts.text: State lawyer advised on April 15, 1965 to move under Art. 227.

anchor.surface_text: On or about April 15, 1965, the State Lawyer in the High Court advised the State to move the High Court under Art. 227 of the Constitution to quash the judgment of the Addl. District Judge dated June 27, 1963 in the three Land Acquisition References

facts.text: Writ petitions under Art. 227 filed on May 17, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly writ petitions under Art. 227 of the Constitution west filed in the High Court on May 17, 1965 to quash the judgment of the Addl. District Judge in the Land Acquisition References.

facts.text: Three appeals against Land Acquisition References filed on July 3, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Three appeals against the three Land Acquisition References Nos. 21 and 40 of 1958 and 13 of 1959 were filed in the,High Court on July 3, 1965.

facts.text: High Court dismissed applications under s.5 on August 18, 1966 for unexplained delay between August 27, 1964 and July 3, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, on June 3, 1966 issued numberice to the respon- dents. After hearing the respondents, the High Court assesed by the companymon order in question on August 18, 1966 dismissing the applications filed by the appellant for excusing the delay under s. 5 of the Limitation Act in filing the three appeals.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside High Court order dated August 18, 1966 and allows applications under s.5, condones delay.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we set aside the judgment and order of the High Court dated August 18, 1966 and allow the appeals. The applications filed by the appellant under S. 5 of the Limitation Act are allowed.

facts.text: First Appeal No. 135 of 1963 by 1st respondent against TS 34/1961 decree pending in High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It is number necessary for us to go into all these aspects more especially when it is brought to our numberice that the 1st respondent has filed an appeal against this decree,, which is pending in the High Court as First Appeal No. 135 of 1963.

facts.text: Objections to execution rejected, matter referred to Legal Remembrancer.

anchor.surface_text: When the objections filed regarding the executability of the Award were rejected, the matter was referred to the Legal Remembrancer, West Bengal, for taking necessary action.

holdings.text: The High Court was not justified in rejecting the applications filed by the appellant under s. 5 of the Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: Hence, we proceed to consider the matter and adjudicate upon the question Whether the High Court was justified in rejecting the applications filed by the appellant under s. 5 of the Limitation Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court order brief, no scrutiny of affidavits, no disbelief of averments or finding of negligence; court examines facts itself due to time elapsed.

holdings.text: The appellant has shown sufficient cause under s. 5 of the Limitation Act for condoning the delay in filing the appeals.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that in the circumstances of this case, the appellant has shown sufficient cause and it is not possible to impute to the appellant want of bona fides or such inaction or negligence as would deprive them of the protection of S. 5 of the Limitation Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No negligence or inaction; diligent steps after discovery of non-filing; liberal construction advances justice; applies precedents like Ramlal v Rewa Coalfields.

holdings.text: The delay between August 27, 1964 and July 3, 1965 has been sufficiently explained, particularly after March 4, 1965 with diligent steps including writ petitions and appeals.

anchor.surface_text: we are of the opinion that after March 4, 1965 the appellant had been taking diligent and active steps to challenge the decision of the Addl. District Judge in the Land Acquisition Reference Cases.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discovery on March 4, 1965; advice April 15; writs May 17; appeals July 3; no denial of facts; High Court attached no importance to prior period.

holdings.text: Mistaken advice given by a legal adviser constitutes sufficient cause under s. 5 and does not amount to negligence.

anchor.surface_text: if a party had acted in a particular manner on a wrong advice given by his Legal Adviser, he cannot be held guilty of negligence so as to disentitle the party to plead sufficient cause under s. 5 of the Limitation Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Judicial Committee in Kunwar Rajendra Singh v Rai Rajeshwar Bali; advice to file Art.227 writs instead of appeals considered.

holdings.text: The same period of limitation and principles under s. 5 apply equally to the State and private litigants; no special liberal construction merely for Government.

anchor.surface_text: the period of limitation applicable both to a private litigant as well as to the State is the same and the same principles are applicable to both the parties

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms respondent's contention; no distinction unless statute provides; fairness to Solicitor General who did not claim differential treatment.

holdings.text: The High Court failed to properly scrutinise the reasons/affidavits provided by the appellant for the delay.

anchor.surface_text: One feature that strikes us on a perusal of the judgment of the High Court is, that there is absolutely no indication that it has disbelieved any of the averments made in the affidavits filed on behalf of the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No reasons given; no rejection as false; no finding of negligence or lack of bona fides; duty to consider merits.

holdings.text: The applications under s. 5 are allowed; delay condoned; High Court order set aside; appeals to be taken on file.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we set aside the judgment and order of the High Court dated August 18, 1966 and allow the appeals. The applications filed by the appellant under S. 5 of the Limitation Act are allowed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative findings on sufficient cause lead to condonation; procedural directions for disposal.

holdings.text: No precise facts constitute 'sufficient cause' under s. 5; depends on case circumstances; delay not due to negligence in necessary steps.

anchor.surface_text: It is not possible to lay down precisely as to what facts or matters would constitute sufficient cause under s. 5, of the Limitation Act. But it may be safely stated that the delay in filing an appeal should not have been for reasons which indicate the partys negligence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restates settled law; illustrative facts not exhaustive; judicial discretion per facts.

holdings.text: Words 'sufficient cause' receive liberal construction to advance substantial justice where no negligence, inaction or want of bona fides.

anchor.surface_text: the words sufficient cause receiving a liberal construction so as to advance substantial justice when no negligence or inaction or want of bona fides is imputable to the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quotes Ramlal v Rewa Coalfields and Madras HC; balances vested right from limitation lapse.

precedents.citation: Ramlal, Motilal and Chhotelal v. Rewa Coalfields Ltd.  1

anchor.surface_text: It has been pointed out by this Court in-Ramlal, Motilal and Chhotelal v. Rewa Coalfields Ltd.  1  as follows In companystruing s. 5 it is relevant to bear in mind two important companysiderations. The first companysideration is that the expiration of the period of limitation prescribed for or making an appeal gives rise to a right in favour of the decree-holder to treat the decree as binding between the parties.

precedents.case_name: Ramlal Motilal and Chhotelal v Rewa Coalfields Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: Construing s. 5 of Limitation Act: two considerations - right vests in decree-holder on expiry of limitation, but court discretion to condone delay for substantial justice
precedents.cited_holding: the expiration of the period of limitation prescribed for or making an appeal gives rise to a right in favour of the decree-holder to treat the decree as binding between the parties... discretion... exercised to advance substantial justice

anchor.surface_text: As has been observed by the Madras High Court in Krishna v. Chattappan 2  s. 5 gives the Court a discretion which in respect of jurisdi ction is to be exercised in the way in which judicial power and discretion ought to be exercised, upon principles which are well understood the words sufficient cause receiving a liberal companystruction go as to advance substantial justice when numbernegligence for inaction number want of bona fide is. imputable to the appellant.

precedents.cited_proposition: s.5 gives court discretion to be exercised judicially with liberal construction of sufficient cause to advance substantial justice absent negligence, inaction or lack of bona fides
precedents.cited_holding: s. 5 gives the Court a discretion which... words sufficient cause receiving a liberal companystruction... to advance substantial justice when numbernegligence... number want of bona fide is imputable to the appellant

precedents.citation: Shakuntala Devi Jain v. Kuntal Kumari and others 1

anchor.surface_text: The observations of the Madras High Court, extracted in the above decision, have again been quoted with approval in Shakuntala Devi Jain v. Kuntal Kumari and others 1 . On the particular facts of the case, this Court held in the said decision that it was number a case where it was possible to impute to the appellant therein want of bonafide or such inaction or negligence as would deprive a party of the protection of s. 5 of the Limitation Act, 1963.

precedents.case_name: Shakuntala Devi Jain v Kuntal Kumari
precedents.cited_proposition: Quoted with approval the liberal construction under s.5; no negligence or inaction imputable to deprive protection of s.5
precedents.cited_holding: it was number a case where it was possible to impute to the appellant therein want of bonafide or such inaction or negligence as would deprive a party of the protection of s. 5

precedents.citation: Ram Narain Joshi v. Parmeshwar Narain Mahta and, others 1

anchor.surface_text: Mr. D. N. Mukherji learned companynsel for the respondents Nos. 2 to 4 invited our attention to the decision of the Judicial companymittee in Ram Narain Joshi v. Parmeshwar Narain Mahta and, others 1 , where the Judicial Committee declined to interfere with the order of the High Court declining to excuse the delay in filing an appeal under s. 5 of the Limitation Act on the ground that numbersufficient cause was shown by the party companycerned.

precedents.case_name: Ram Narain Joshi v Parmeshwar Narain Mahta
precedents.cited_proposition: Judicial Committee declined to interfere with High Court refusing condonation under s.5 for lack of sufficient cause after consideration of reasons

precedents.citation: Kunwar Rajendra Singh v. Rai Rajeshwar Bali and others 1

anchor.surface_text: But, as pointed out by the Judicial Committee in Kunwar Rajendra Singh v. Rai Rajeshwar Bali and others 1 , if a party had acted in a particular manner on a wrong advice given by his Legal Adviser, he cannot be held guilty of negligence so as to disentitle the party to plead sufficient cause under s. 5 of the Limitation Act.

precedents.case_name: Kunwar Rajendra Singh v Rai Rajeshwar Bali
precedents.cited_proposition: Mistaken advice by legal adviser may constitute sufficient cause under s.5, not negligence
precedents.cited_holding: Mistaken advice given by a legal practitioner may in the circumstances of a particular case give rise to sufficient cause within the section though there is cer- tainly numbergeneral doctrine which saves parties from the results of wrong advice

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, inclined to allow the three applications filed by the appellant in the High Court under s. 5 of the Limitation Act and to condone the delay in filing the three appeals. In the result, we set aside the judgment and order of the High Court dated August 18, 1966 and allow the appeals. The applications filed by the appellant under S. 5 of the Limitation Act are allowed.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court judgment and order dated August 18, 1966 set aside; appeals allowed; delay under s. 5 Limitation Act condoned; underlying appeals directed to be taken on file by High Court for disposal on merits
directions: The High Court will take up the three appeals on its file and dispose them of according to law.
It is needless to state that the High Court will consider the question of giving a very early disposal to the appeals.
It is open to the High Court to give appropriate directions regarding the land acquisition amount.

anchor.surface_text: Hence, we proceed to consider the matter and adjudicate upon the question Whether the High Court was justified in rejecting the applications filed by the appellant under s. 5 of the Limitation Act.

We are, therefore, inclined to allow the three applications filed by the appellant in the High Court under s. 5 of the Limitation Act and to condone the delay in filing the three appeals. In the result, we set aside the judgment and order of the High Court dated August 18, 1966 and allow the appeals. The applications filed by the appellant under S. 5 of the Limitation Act are allowed.

edges.explanation: Holding that sufficient cause shown under s.5 addresses the issue of whether sufficient cause for condoning delay

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that in the circumstances of this case, the appellant has shown sufficient cause and it is not possible to impute to the appellant want of bona fides or such inaction or negligence as would deprive them of the protection of S. 5 of the Limitation Act.

We are, therefore, inclined to allow the three applications filed by the appellant in the High Court under s. 5 of the Limitation Act and to condone the delay in filing the three appeals. In the result, we set aside the judgment and order of the High Court dated August 18, 1966 and allow the appeals. The applications filed by the appellant under S. 5 of the Limitation Act are allowed.
we are of the opinion that after March 4, 1965 the appellant had been taking diligent and active steps to challenge the decision of the Addl. District Judge in the Land Acquisition Reference Cases.

We are, therefore, inclined to allow the three applications filed by the appellant in the High Court under s. 5 of the Limitation Act and to condone the delay in filing the three appeals. In the result, we set aside the judgment and order of the High Court dated August 18, 1966 and allow the appeals. The applications filed by the appellant under S. 5 of the Limitation Act are allowed.

anchor.surface_text: One feature that strikes us on a perusal of the judgment of the High Court is, that there is absolutely no indication that it has disbelieved any of the averments made in the affidavits filed on behalf of the appellant.

We are, therefore, inclined to allow the three applications filed by the appellant in the High Court under s. 5 of the Limitation Act and to condone the delay in filing the three appeals. In the result, we set aside the judgment and order of the High Court dated August 18, 1966 and allow the appeals. The applications filed by the appellant under S. 5 of the Limitation Act are allowed.
